body:
>If you respect them they will respect you.

This is not my experience. I have been repeatedly pulled over by local cops just for being on the road in the wee hours of the morning. I have been harassed when I had clearly been crying and was in a poor emotional state. I have been pulled over without reason. I have personally witnessed officers lying to the public, giving unlawful commands, and approaching civilians eating at a private location to verbally harass and embarrass them. I have also witnessed a family member being arrested due to paperwork mismanagement and the officer insisting he was, "only following orders." I also know a distant family member with untreated mental illnesses who got advice from other sheriff's officers on how to game  selection process to not flag the psych tests. 

I do not support defunding the police. I do support a more rigorous selection process and more intensive training, particularly in the areas of conflict deescalation and social interactions.

post.title: I feel like most police are really nice guys. People just are assholes to them

body:
I am always nice and respectful. I have had more bad interactions with police being unnecessary dicks or trying to get me to talk myself into admission of some non existent crime more times than Ive had them help me with anything or just have a normal interaction.

Once a kid busted out the windows in my families restaurant, I gave the officer the description, he proceeded to tell me I couldnt have seen all the detail I was explaining, and how did I see it etc. Very rude about it. He never let me explain that I heard this kid coming down the street screaming and swearing, popped out my window and watched him punch out the glass and look to the sky and scream.  Officer asshole just didnt want to hear any of it.

Another time I was pulled over at 10:30ish on a Friday.  Cops didnt ask for ID or anything, just kept trying to get me to admit I had been drinking, I had not.  "How many drinks have you had tonight?" "Any beer in the trunk?" "Smells like alcohol in here". There was no beer and I had just got out of work. They never did any tests or anything, just let me go after it was clear I wasn't going to agree to let them search the car.

I was in a car accident around 2008, 4 way stop I was not at fault thanks to bystanders who saw it all.
Lady ran her stop sign while I was crossing and T-boned me. It wasnt super fast, so no injury for me, but after it happened I drove to the roadside so traffic could get by(it was blocking both lanes  4 lane, uncross able median).
First thing the officer does is start questioning me about how fast I was going (because I had moved the car) and did I know about the stop sign. I said "What? she ran the stop sign and hit me after it was my right of way, I moved the car after the accident" He wouldnt listen and started writing me a ticket after talking to the lady who hit me.  Then, thank god 2-3 people overheard all this, me pleading that I didnt run the sign and they came over and told the cop what happened. He finally relented.  Still on the accident report he had written something to the effect of "Red car accelerated too quickly to safely avoid collision." I wasn't flooring it out the stop, the lady was looking in the back of her car at her grandkid and just drove out blind.

Im not even going to get into college incidents. I have little love for police, I wouldnt call 911 for myself unless it was severe personal injury. I have come to believe I'm better off handling it on my own anyway.

I do agree that there are people who essentially bring it on themselves by being jackasses and fighting with police, but Ive seen way too many incidents with cops just swinging around their power dicks and abusing and intimidating innocent civilians.  

I would go so far as to say the good/bad split is nearly 50/50, and that is unacceptable.

body:
All the cops I know personally are... how to describe it? They’re not corrupt, but because they’re police officers, they let their kids think that they’re invincible when it comes to breaking the law. The police’s kids I knew growing up used drugs, drank underage, and drove underage (kids as young as 8 driving trucks on public roads). Since their parents know (and are) the law enforcement, they get off free if they’re ever caught. They never got caught though since everyone in the law enforcement are pretty tight knit around here.

I personally have never had a good experience with law enforcement even though I’ve never broken the law.

post.title: I feel like most police are really nice guys. People just are assholes to them

body:
I spent a lot of my early adulthood working at bars and doing construction. I've heard stories like yours a lot. After knowing those people a little while I started to notice that they had these same issues with just about everyone else too. Their managers were unfair, their romantic partners, professors, and especially their parents. It had nothing to do with their behavior, their problems with drugs or alcohol, or their innate defiance of authority. The weird part was that i lived in circumstances similar to these people. I lived in a bad part of town, drove an old crappy car with expired license, insurance and tag, left work at wee hours because I just closed the bar and all of my interactions with police have been respectful on both mine and the officers' side. Even the cop who threw my ass in lock-up for driving under suspension was cool. Not even kidding one cop suggested a new car insurance company when I told him I couldn't afford the car insurance I had, turns out my previous company was charging me double the price of the one he suggested. 

Just something I think about sometimes.

I have also witnessed a family member being arrested due to paperwork mismanagement and the officer insisting he was, "only following orders." I also know a distant family member with untreated mental illnesses who got advice from other sheriff's officers on how to game  selection process to not flag the psych tests. 

I do not support defunding the police. I do support a more rigorous selection process and more intensive training, particularly in the areas of conflict deescalation and social interactions.

If you respect them they will respect you.

This is not my experience. I have been repeatedly pulled over by local cops just for being on the road in the wee hours of the morning. I do not support defunding the police. I do support a more rigorous selection process and more intensive training, particularly in the areas of conflict deescalation and social interactions.

body:
Police are just like any other group - a few asshole and a lot of really normal folks.  Everyone who gets into law enforcement does it for a reason - for some people it's as simple as a pretty good-paying career with advancement opportunities where you have a chance to help people on a daily basis.  For some people, it's about exercising power and control over others because you don't have much in your own life.  Just like in most populations, the winners FAR outweigh the losers.  The only problem comes in that we never HEAR about the positive, chill cops.  We only hear bout the assholes.  

HOAs are the same.  You never hear about the positive ones, you only ever hear horror stories.

body:
I am not a cantankerous person. I'm very high in agreeableness and despise conflict. I do not invite this kind of behavior due to being an abrasive person, if that's what you're implying. 

Funny enough, the most pleasant experience I've had with an officer was when I was immediately aggressive with the officer. I was pulled over mid day, asked for license/registration, and I asked why I was pulled over because the officer had given me no reason. It's the only time in living memory I've been anything but polite and respectful towards a police officer.

parent.body:
I spent a lot of my early adulthood working at bars and doing construction. I've heard stories like yours a lot. After knowing those people a little while I started to notice that they had these same issues with just about everyone else too. Their managers were unfair, their romantic partners, professors, and especially their parents. It had nothing to do with their behavior, their problems with drugs or alcohol, or their innate defiance of authority. The weird part was that i lived in circumstances similar to these people. I lived in a bad part of town, drove an old crappy car with expired license, insurance and tag, left work at wee hours because I just closed the bar and all of my interactions with police have been respectful on both mine and the officers' side. Even the cop who threw my ass in lock-up for driving under suspension was cool. Not even kidding one cop suggested a new car insurance company when I told him I couldn't afford the car insurance I had, turns out my previous company was charging me double the price of the one he suggested. 

Just something I think about sometimes.

body:
I disagree. Police are only more kind to the extent they are expected to be more kind, because they have an image they have to uphold. Just like a cashier is more kind taking your order than she would likely be passing by in the streets. Furthermore, if a solid 3/4 of people are not 'really nice' why would you think police officers, who tend to be power seeking and alpha type people, are actually really nice?

So to summarize my opinion, they are definitely more nice than they are being portrayed by the media and BLM/antifa and what-not, but they are not more nice than any other group of people.

body:
False dichotomy.

Of course, many officers are reasonable. The problem is that the system is rotten to the bone and completely incapable of weeding out the bad apples.

Most citizens, too, are reasonable. But criminals do exist, which is why a police force is needed in the first place.

As long as you're not an immediate threat to anyone's life or health, deadly force by the police is absolutely unacceptable. Otherwise, you live in a fascist police state.

body: There are bad apples in every scenario, however I know a lot of cops who I consider wonderful people. These people have some of the worst working conditions, are in many life threatening situations, and subjected to some of the worst members of society repeatedly. They do their job to get criminals off of the streets only for the system to put them right back on the same streets for the same cops to have to continually deal with. Frustration is a factor of their everyday lifestyle indeed. Having said that, I also know a few who walk around on a power trip, like throwing their weight around and abuse the power they have. No profession is free from bad people. I think it all comes down to the how they are managed, the person to whom they answer to at the end of the day. Where I live we have a wonderful sheriff who holds his deputies accountable for their actions. There was one in particular I can remember had two complaints, our sheriff pulled the tapes, reviewed them with the officer explaining what he had done wrong and warned him this would be the only warning he would receive. He was subsequently fired a few weeks later.

body:
I mean any service job will make you look at people like cattle at some point. Waiters are some of the most cynical fucks you'll ever meet. My friend was the most straight edge Catholic boy growing up. Never touched any drug, did a ton of after school sports, helped the community volunteering, etc. 3 years of being a first responder (EMT) in a big city. He is now a borderline alcoholic, denounces gods existance because he rationalized there's no way there's a god because of the amount of small kids with gunshot wounds he's had to try and save, and he now only expects people to be shitty now because all he sees is the worst of humanity on a daily basis. Doing that 40+ hours a week every week will get to anyone.    
    
It's easy for a bunch of well to do desk jockeys to judge police for being shit heads, yes some are. But I think they're the majority of them are overworked and have PTSD from the crazy shit they have seen and stress they experience. And the people who critize them have not even the slightest idea of the sheer intensity the job can have, like the biggest struggle they have is that the office is too cold and barb is a loud eater. The majority of people complaining about police have never, ever experienced the mental sledgehammer being a first responder is.    
    
And this is why every citizen should have to at least go to boot camp when they graduate highschool in America. Learn discipline and true struggle.    
    
Thanks for coming to my Ted talk

I said I was aggressive, not that I was hostile. I firmly asked why I was pulled over when I was not told immediately. I didn't do anything hostile or alarming. 

I also didn't bully anyone into action which violated their rights, I didn't lie to the officer who pulled me over, and I didn't actively break any laws. 

Please explain to me how firmly requesting the reason I was pulled over ought to give police officers a right to behave in a hostile manner that infringes on the rights of the people they are sworn to protect.

Sounds just like the firm aggressive stance they often end up taking with people. A stance which many people then go on to complain about how they were intimidated etc. 

I never said that it gives them the right to infringe on others. That is something you've created in your head. You're really beginning to sound like some of the bad ones now. Aggression, double standards, forming narratives that wern't there. Next you'll be putting 6 warning shots into me.

parent.body:
I said I was aggressive, not that I was hostile. I firmly asked why I was pulled over when I was not told immediately. I didn't do anything hostile or alarming. 

I also didn't bully anyone into action which violated their rights, I didn't lie to the officer who pulled me over, and I didn't actively break any laws. 

Please explain to me how firmly requesting the reason I was pulled over ought to give police officers a right to behave in a hostile manner that infringes on the rights of the people they are sworn to protect.

post.body:
I feel like most police are respectful. It’s just that people resist arrest so much. When ever a police officer pulls me over i immediately show him my ID and insurance. And I’m respectful and they let me go

We just have a demographic of people that think it’s okay to disrespect police. If you respect them they will respect you. They have laws to enforce and many people think they are above the law

body:
I am not from the US nor do i live in the US, but many people hate cops where i am from too, but i am always nice to them, multiple people in my family are police officers.

Whenever i see cops on the street i always say "Good morning", "Good day" and so on, they're one of the few people i actually say "Good morning" too, normally i just say "Morning" to people.

body: Defunding the police is not the same as abolishing them. The goal is to redirect some (not all) part of police budgets to things like mental health facilities, education, or infrastructure. As it is, police are overburdened and are expected to answer calls regarding crime as well as mental health, and allowing citizens better access to mental health facilities is a win for everyone. Transparency (especially records of police misconduct) is also welcome.
